desc: MDM4 encodes a negative regulator of the p53 tumor suppressor. MDM4 is amplified or overexpressed in a diverse range of cancers resulting in aberrant p53 activity.

The MDM4 gene encodes a negative regulator of the p53 tumor suppressor, the most frequently inactivated gene in human cancer (PMID: 25960041, 22154076). The two major negative regulators of p53, MDM2 and MDM4, function by blocking its N-terminal transactivation domain (PMID: 21730163). In addition, MDM4 stimulates the MDM2-catalysed ubiquitination of p53 which leads to its degradation (PMID: 14507994, 12162806). Similar to MDM2, MDM4 is deregulated in several tumor types such as cutaneous melanoma, primary breast tumors, retinoblastomas (PMID: 17080083), Ewing sarcomas (PMID: 21098696) and gliomas (PMID: 22820643, 15199139, 12640683, 11280734). In the overwhelming majority of cases, cells with deregulated MDM2 or MDM4 retain wild-type p53 (PMID: 23303139). Thus, inhibition of the p53 interaction with MDM2 or MDM4 is an attractive candidate strategy for treatment of cancer via the reactivation of p53 (PMID: 25621298, 21098696, 20080970, 14704432, 25201201, 23374098, 16905541, 16540668).
